citeinfo.title: Doubly-labeled Water, Deuterium Dilution, Body Mass, and Blood Biochemistry Data from Female Polar Bears (Ursus maritimus) in the Southern Beaufort Sea by the USGS in April 2014-2016

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.othercit: Suggested citation: Pagano, Anthony M., 2018, Doubly-labeled Water, Deuterium Dilution, Body Mass, and Blood Biochemistry Data from Female Polar Bears (Ursus maritimus) in the Southern Beaufort Sea by the USGS in April 2014-2016: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F7XW4H0P.

citeinfo.origin: USGS Alaska Science Center, Polar Bear Research Program
citeinfo.title: Changing Arctic Ecosystems: The effects of declining sea ice on polar bear behaviors and energetic rates

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

descript.abstract: This dataset contains specific activity measures of deuterium oxide and oxygen-18, body mass, and blood biochemistry (blood urea nitrogen and creatinine) data for 9 female polar bears without dependent young in the southern Beaufort Sea in April 2014-2016.
descript.purpose: These data were collected to gain insights into the spring field metabolic rate, body composition, and feeding success of female polar bears without dependent young in the southern Beaufort Sea.

theme.themekt: NASA GCMD Earth Science Keywords Thesaurus

It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate limitations, restrictions or intended use.

citeinfo.title: High-energy, high-fat lifestyle challenges an Arctic apex predator, the polar bear

attracc.attraccr: Measures of specific activity were made by Metabolic Solutions, Inc. (Nashua, NH, USA).

dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented. Bears in 2015 and 2016 were dosed with deuterium oxide at recapture. Bears in 2014 were not dosed with deuterium oxide at recapture.

method.methdesc: Specific activity of deuterium oxide and oxygen-18 in serum samples collected from 9 female polar bears without dependent young captured in April 2014-2016 were measured by Metabolic Solutions, Inc. (Nashua, NH).

citeinfo.origin: Thorsen, T., T. Shriver, N. Racine, B.A. Richman, and D. A. Schoeller
citeinfo.title: Doubly labeled water analysis using cavity ring-down spectroscopy

method.methdesc: Clinical serum chemistry parameters of blood urea nitrogen and creatinine were measured from 9 female polar bears without dependent young captured in April 2014-2016.

citeinfo.origin: Norberg, S.E., V.N. Burkanov, and R.D. Andrews
citeinfo.title: Serum chemistry values of free-ranging, lactating northern fur seals (Callorhinus ursinus)

method.methdesc: Bears that had not been previously captured were aged based on counts of cementum annuli from an extracted vestigial premolar.

citeinfo.title: Evaluation of age determination of polar bears by counts of cementum growth layer groups

procstep.procdesc: To measure the specific activity of deuterium oxide and oxygen-18 in serum samples, we immobilized 9 female polar bears without dependent young. Following immobilization, we inserted an external jugular catheter to facilitate blood sampling and administration of isotopes. An initial blood sample was collected to serve as a baseline measure of 18O (oxygen-18) and 2H (deuterium). The bear was then injected intravenously with a precisely weighed dose containing 0.12 – 0.25 g/kg of 97% enriched 18O (Isoflex USA, San Francisco, CA) and 0.06 – 0.10 g/kg of 99.9% enriched 2H (Isotec, Inc., Miamisburg, OH or Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc., Tewksbury, MA) with NaCl added to make it 0.9% isotonic and sterilized using a 0.2 µ Millipore filter. On injection, the syringe was back washed with blood three times to ensure all the DLW had been injected into the bear. The bear was kept immobilized for 2 hours after the injection of DLW to allow isotope equilibration. We collected serial blood samples 60, 90, and 120 minutes after dosing. We recaptured bears 8 – 11 days later to obtain a blood sample to measure final enrichment. At recapture, we weighed bears to measure changes in body mass. In 2015 and 2016, we dosed recaptured bears with 0.09 – 0.14 g/kg of 99.9% enriched deuterated water (D2O, Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc.) and collected serial blood samples 60 and 90 minutes after dosing to measure changes in body composition between captures. Blood was collected in 10 ml glass evacuated tubes without anticoagulants (Serum Vacutainer, Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ) and centrifuged to separate serum from red blood cells. Serum was stored frozen in 2 ml cryogenic vials (Corning, Inc., Corning, NY) at -20°C until analysis.
Serum samples were analyzed for the concentrations of 18O and 2H by Metabolic Solutions, Inc. (Nashua, NH).

To obtain blood urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations, serum samples from capture and recapture were analyzed using an Abaxis Vetscan VS2 chemistry analyzer (Abaxis, Inc., Union City, CA). Each sample was analyzed twice with the exception of bears 8 and 9 whose samples were only analyzed once.
Age was determined by counts of cementum annuli from an extracted vestigial premolar by C-D & Associates Biological Consulting (Spruce Grove, AB, Canada).
We measured total body mass at each capture using an electronic load cell suspended from an aluminum tripod.

enttyp.enttypd: Metabolic rate, body composition, and blood biochemistry from 9 female polar bears in the southern Beaufort Sea in April 2014-2016.

attr.attrdef: Sample identifier.
Data are from the animal's first capture or from a subsequent recapture.
The age of the bear in years.
Total body mass of the bear in kg.
Date time (mmm dd, yyyy hh:mm) isotopes were injected into the bear in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).
Date time (mmm dd, yyyy hh:mm) final enrichment of isotopes were measured from the bear via a blood sample in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).
Background concentration of deuterium oxide in the bear as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Background concentration of oxygen-18 in the bear as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide in the bear 60 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 in the bear 60 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide in the bear 90 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 in the bear 90 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide in the bear 120 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 in the bear 120 minutes after injection as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide in the bear at final enrichment as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 in the bear at final enrichment as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide injected into the bear as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 injected into the bear as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of deuterium oxide in a control sample of tap-water as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Concentration of oxygen-18 in a control sample of tap-water as a delta relative to the Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (V-SMOW).
Mass of doubly-labeled water (2H18O) injected into the bear in grams.
Mass of deuterium oxide injected into the bear in grams.
Mass of doubly-labeled water (2H18O) or deuterium oxide sample that was analyzed to assess concentrations in grams.
Mass of control sample of tap water in grams.
Blood urea nitrogen concentration in mg/dl from first analysis.
Creatinine concentration in mg/dl from first analysis.
Blood urea nitrogen concentration in mg/dl from second analysis.
Creatinine concentration in mg/dl from second analysis.
